Editor's Note: In 1933, John D. and Mack D. Rust, brothers,
invented a mechanical cotton picker, which, when demonstrated at
the Delta Experiment Station, Mississippi, picked more cotton in
seven and a half hours than is picked by a good hand-picker in an
entire season of three and one-half months. This invention was the
first of its kind to be successful, although attempts to deveL'op a
mechanical picker date back to 1857, and more than 800 patents
have been granted since that time. The International Harvester
Company is said to have spent three million dollars trying to pro-

U. D. C. CHAPTER
DONATES PORTRAIT
OF SIDNEY LANIER
The Petersburg Chapter of the
United Daughters of the Confederacy last Wednesday presented a
portrait of Sidney Lanier to the
Petersburg High School (Petersburg, Va.). Mrs. R. T. Meade, president of the chapter, made the presentation.
Dr. Lanier was lecturer in English literature at the Hopkins from
1879 to 1881. He is known as one
of the greatest poets ever to come
out of the South.
Sidney Lanier's granddaughter,
Miss Nancy Lanier, works at the
reserve desk in the Main Library.
At present she is on leave of absence and has gone to her home in
Cambridge, Md., for a month. Her
place is being taken by Miss Beatrice Blakslee, who has been working with the Page School Library.

Musicians Ho!

Perhaps the Club would not feel
that it could give two concerts of
the scope of Friday's; but they might
at least offer two or three leas ambitious programs besides the big concert. They certainly have the talent
necessary; and if they could do nothing more, they might give assembly
programs. It appears that the Barnstormers are acceding to the demands
of the campus, and are preparing to
give,at least one more show this year.
We hope the Musical Club will follow
suit. There seems to be just as much
demand for it.
These young musicians seem to
have gone a long way towards their
avowed goal of making themselves as
noteworthy an organization as the
lacrosse team or the School of Medicine. There were very few exceptions
to the universal acclaim for their performance Friday.
We couldn't help thinking, as we
looked over the membership of the
Club, that here is the real Hopkins
spirit. Whatever complaints may be
made against the rest of the campus
for its lack of spirit, here is an organization which draws a large membership from all the different schools
—Engineers, Dimness students, students from the College of Arts and
Sciences—language students, chemistry majors, students from the history stacks—and joins them in an organization that really shows the Hopkins spirit.
It was an encouraging sight. A little more of that sort of thing, and the
bugbear of an uninterested student
body and a "dead" campus might be
N. P.
•
eliminated.

Letters To The Editor
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER
Dear Sir:
Walking up the south steps of Gilman Hall today I was greeted by the
sight of debris in the form of burst
paper cups littering the various
flights, and also by what appeared to
be a small flood spattered on the newly-cleaned walls.
It appears that some of our R. 0.
T. C. students, disordered in intellect,
who have deranged bomb-dropping
tendencies, had childishly filled paper
drinking cups with water, and had
proceeded to drop them from the
heights of the third and fourth floors
to the basement.
This is supposed to be a university,
not a kindergarten, and individuals
possessing such a stinted sense of
humor do not belong here. Let's take
steps to stop these putatively funny
tactics, and save some poor unfortunate from being drowned by these
redolent infants. The Student Council
should make it a point to stop these
infamous miscreants.
GORDON GRAHAME DUCE.
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
In commenting upon track, it is
not my purpose in this letter to distract attention or interest in any way
from lacrosse, which is as it should
be, by virtue of its accomplishments,
the predominant sport at the Hopkins.
The purpose is rather to acquaint
some non-participators of the vernal

sports with track as a spring sport.
It is felt that there are many on
the campus who are potential track
men, perhaps not to the degree of
being stars and for this reason they
feel they should refrain from entering the sport. It is precisely this notion which this letter proposes to
clarify.
To the knowledge of the author,
track is a sport which stands apart
from most sports, not so much as an
outstanding sport but rather for its
exception in function. It is not a
sport where each member of the team
is dependent upon one another as a
group—the dependence is upon the
track man as an individual performer. He cannot have an off-day as easily as a member of a cooperative
team and let his teammates carry
the brunt of the burden.
This, no doubt, is the reason for
findging so many stars in track. But
the stars on a team are necessarily
limited and it is in this regard that
the sport, track, may function as a
team. Usually it takes more than just
the stars to win a meet. It takes the
second and third place men to add
their bit to the score.
Time and again it has been emphasized by coaches that in track there
is always room for the fellow with the
"guts" to stick. Perhaps not to become a star, but to become an important factor on the team.
Spiked Shoe Society.
Tivirta LEBIMIFELD,

Hopkins, Florida
Debaters Argue On
Munitions Sales
Arguing on the question: Resolved,
That the nations of the world shall
agree to prohibit the international
shipment of arms and munitions, the
Hopkins debating squad, taking the
affirmative side, met a team from the
University of Florida last Friday in
Gilman 205.
After introductory remarks by Dr.
Clifford Lyons, the debate was opened
by Grossman of the Hopkins, who
proposed breaking up the munition
makers' hold on the world, revealed
by the Nye Senate investigations.
This could be accomplished, he said,
by putting into effect an international
embargo on arms and munitions.
For the negative side, Errs of Florida pointed out the helpless position
that such an embargo would place
those countries of the world, who
would then have no sources for the
arms which both the affirmative and
negative admitted necessary for world
peace. He also ridiculed Grossman's
desire to have his embargo supported
by the signatures of the countries involved. Errs cited previous betrayal
of signatures on various treaties by

One of the rarest of the 475,000
bound volumes which fill the
shelves of the Hopkins library is
the first edition of Warner's Albions England, printed in 1586.
The book was purchased by the
Tudor and Stuart Club in 1934
from Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach, New
York and Philadelphia dealer and
collector in rare literature.
Only two other copies of this
vrst edition are known to exist today and, ironically enough, not one
of these remains in England. One
copy has passed into the hands of
a private collector in New York
City, while the other is the property of the Huntington Library in
San Marino, Cal.
Albion's England is an historical
epic glorifying the British Isles
and is written in rhyming verse.
Its author, William Warner, was
the first to popularize the historical
epic in Elizabethan times, but in
recent years, he has fallen to such
obscurity that the Encyclopedia
Britannica no longer gives him
separate listing.

Badminton Meets Planned
A schedule for the badminton team
is now being drawn up, and will include matches with the Y. M. C. A.,
the Y. M. H. A., two private organizations, and a church group. The
match with the Y. M. C. A. will take
place on March 30.
The team will be drawn from the
Individuals appearing on the top of
the badminton ladder standings. The
tournament will come to a close at the
end of this month, according to Reuben Baer, head of the tourney.
Hopkins has introduced the game
to the leaders of the Playground Athletic League of Baltimore, who are
now contemplating the organization
of badminton as a playground activity during the summer. It is hoped
that during next winter, a Baltimore
badminton team will be formed.

Because you cannot make a good cigarette
from just one year's crop there are today
miles of warehouses filled with cigarette tobaccos from the crops of 1931-32-33-34—most of
it for Chesterfield cigarettes.
Just as money accumulates interest, two
and a half years of ageing makes these tobaccos
milder and naturally sweeter.
Think what this means—an eighty-five million dollar reason why men and women who
smoke Chesterfields will always enjoy a milder,
better-tasting cigarette.

Editor's Note: In 1933, John D. and Mack D. Rust, brothers,
invented a mechanical cotton picker, which, when demonstrated at
the Delta Experiment Station, Mississippi, picked more cotton in
seven and a half hours than is picked by a good hand-picker in an
entire season of three and one-half months. This invention was the
first of its kind to be successful, although attempts to deveL'op a
mechanical picker date back to 1857, and more than 800 patents
have been granted since that time. The International Harvester
Company is said to have spent three million dollars trying to pro-

U. D. C. CHAPTER
DONATES PORTRAIT
OF SIDNEY LANIER
The Petersburg Chapter of the
United Daughters of the Confederacy last Wednesday presented a
portrait of Sidney Lanier to the
Petersburg High School (Petersburg, Va.). Mrs. R. T. Meade, president of the chapter, made the presentation.
Dr. Lanier was lecturer in English literature at the Hopkins from
1879 to 1881. He is known as one
of the greatest poets ever to come
out of the South.
Sidney Lanier's granddaughter,
Miss Nancy Lanier, works at the
reserve desk in the Main Library.
At present she is on leave of absence and has gone to her home in
Cambridge, Md., for a month. Her
place is being taken by Miss Beatrice Blakslee, who has been working with the Page School Library.

Musicians Ho!

Perhaps the Club would not feel
that it could give two concerts of
the scope of Friday's; but they might
at least offer two or three leas ambitious programs besides the big concert. They certainly have the talent
necessary; and if they could do nothing more, they might give assembly
programs. It appears that the Barnstormers are acceding to the demands
of the campus, and are preparing to
give,at least one more show this year.
We hope the Musical Club will follow
suit. There seems to be just as much
demand for it.
These young musicians seem to
have gone a long way towards their
avowed goal of making themselves as
noteworthy an organization as the
lacrosse team or the School of Medicine. There were very few exceptions
to the universal acclaim for their performance Friday.
We couldn't help thinking, as we
looked over the membership of the
Club, that here is the real Hopkins
spirit. Whatever complaints may be
made against the rest of the campus
for its lack of spirit, here is an organization which draws a large membership from all the different schools
—Engineers, Dimness students, students from the College of Arts and
Sciences—language students, chemistry majors, students from the history stacks—and joins them in an organization that really shows the Hopkins spirit.
It was an encouraging sight. A little more of that sort of thing, and the
bugbear of an uninterested student
body and a "dead" campus might be
N. P.
•
eliminated.

Letters To The Editor
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER
Dear Sir:
Walking up the south steps of Gilman Hall today I was greeted by the
sight of debris in the form of burst
paper cups littering the various
flights, and also by what appeared to
be a small flood spattered on the newly-cleaned walls.
It appears that some of our R. 0.
T. C. students, disordered in intellect,
who have deranged bomb-dropping
tendencies, had childishly filled paper
drinking cups with water, and had
proceeded to drop them from the
heights of the third and fourth floors
to the basement.
This is supposed to be a university,
not a kindergarten, and individuals
possessing such a stinted sense of
humor do not belong here. Let's take
steps to stop these putatively funny
tactics, and save some poor unfortunate from being drowned by these
redolent infants. The Student Council
should make it a point to stop these
infamous miscreants.
GORDON GRAHAME DUCE.
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
In commenting upon track, it is
not my purpose in this letter to distract attention or interest in any way
from lacrosse, which is as it should
be, by virtue of its accomplishments,
the predominant sport at the Hopkins.
The purpose is rather to acquaint
some non-participators of the vernal

sports with track as a spring sport.
It is felt that there are many on
the campus who are potential track
men, perhaps not to the degree of
being stars and for this reason they
feel they should refrain from entering the sport. It is precisely this notion which this letter proposes to
clarify.
To the knowledge of the author,
track is a sport which stands apart
from most sports, not so much as an
outstanding sport but rather for its
exception in function. It is not a
sport where each member of the team
is dependent upon one another as a
group—the dependence is upon the
track man as an individual performer. He cannot have an off-day as easily as a member of a cooperative
team and let his teammates carry
the brunt of the burden.
This, no doubt, is the reason for
findging so many stars in track. But
the stars on a team are necessarily
limited and it is in this regard that
the sport, track, may function as a
team. Usually it takes more than just
the stars to win a meet. It takes the
second and third place men to add
their bit to the score.
Time and again it has been emphasized by coaches that in track there
is always room for the fellow with the
"guts" to stick. Perhaps not to become a star, but to become an important factor on the team.
Spiked Shoe Society.

Hopkins, Florida
Debaters Argue On
Munitions Sales
Arguing on the question: Resolved,
That the nations of the world shall
agree to prohibit the international
shipment of arms and munitions, the
Hopkins debating squad, taking the
affirmative side, met a team from the
University of Florida last Friday in
Gilman 205.
After introductory remarks by Dr.
Clifford Lyons, the debate was opened
by Grossman of the Hopkins, who
proposed breaking up the munition
makers' hold on the world, revealed
by the Nye Senate investigations.
This could be accomplished, he said,
by putting into effect an international
embargo on arms and munitions.
For the negative side, Errs of Florida pointed out the helpless position
that such an embargo would place
those countries of the world, who
would then have no sources for the
arms which both the affirmative and
negative admitted necessary for world
peace. He also ridiculed Grossman's
desire to have his embargo supported
by the signatures of the countries involved. Errs cited previous betrayal
of signatures on various treaties by

The Blue Moon Orchestra of

One of the rarest of the 475,000
bound volumes which fill the
shelves of the Hopkins library is
the first edition of Warner's Albions England, printed in 1586.
The book was purchased by the
Tudor and Stuart Club in 1934
from Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach, New
York and Philadelphia dealer and
collector in rare literature.
Only two other copies of this
vrst edition are known to exist today and, ironically enough, not one
of these remains in England. One
copy has passed into the hands of
a private collector in New York
City, while the other is the property of the Huntington Library in
San Marino, Cal.
Albion's England is an historical
epic glorifying the British Isles
and is written in rhyming verse.
Its author, William Warner, was
the first to popularize the historical
epic in Elizabethan times, but in
recent years, he has fallen to such
obscurity that the Encyclopedia
Britannica no longer gives him
separate listing.

Margolis, who will be a senior next
year, played on the team during his
qrst two years. This year, however,
because of an unusually heavy schedule, he was not able to report to the
squad until the last three weeks of
the campaign. Consequently, he saw
ittle action.
A native of Montgomery, West
Virginia, George played freshman ball
at Montgomery High School and followed this with three years of varsity competition on a team which held
the sectional championship for six
consecutive seasons.
Entering Hopkins in the fall of
1932, he immediately went out for the
basketball team and made an exceptionally good showing in his first year
of collegiate play. He saw action in
all but three minutes of the regular
playing time.
In addition to being captain-elect
of next year's quint, Margolis was
recently elected chancellor of Pi
Lambda Phi fraternity.
At the meeting also, Abe Edelmann
was made manager, succeeding Stewart Collenberg, and Jules Dietz was
appointed junior manager.

victory with the high point score of
279. Caplan starred for the Hopkins
with a score of 271.

Badminton Meets Planned
A schedule for the badminton team
is now being drawn up, and will include matches with the Y. M. C. A.,
the Y. M. H. A., two private organizations, and a church group. The
match with the Y. M. C. A. will take
place on March 30.
The team will be drawn from the
Individuals appearing on the top of
the badminton ladder standings. The
tournament will come to a close at the
end of this month, according to Reuben Baer, head of the tourney.
Hopkins has introduced the game
to the leaders of the Playground Athletic League of Baltimore, who are
now contemplating the organization
of badminton as a playground activity during the summer. It is hoped
that during next winter, a Baltimore
badminton team will be formed.

Because you cannot make a good cigarette
from just one year's crop there are today

Just as money accumulates interest, two
and a half years of ageing makes these tobaccos
milder and naturally sweeter.
